Did I mention he was recently re-elected by a VERY healthy margin... President Lincoln said you can fool some of the people all of the time and all of the people some of the time but you can't fool all of the people all of the time... the newness of President Obama wore off several years ago and yet he was re-elected.... you folks need to start getting your news and facts from more objective news sources. FOX news? doesn't count. Oh forgot to mention it was President Nixon who championed and passed the affirmative action law back in the 70s, google it to understand his position.

Topic.Title: WHAT ABOUT THE 10 BILLION DOLLAR PENSION LIABILITY THAT CANNOT BE FIXED?

Message.Msg: Like many of us less risky returns for T's pension assets are almost non existent in this economy and the recovery is sick in spite of what others around here suggest ad nauseum. From T's recent SEC filing: "...due to the continued uncertainty in the securities markets and U.S. economy in 2013, we have lowered our expected long-term rate of return on asset assumption to 7.75%." If you want to see pension messes, check out the number and size of public sector pensions and related under funded obligations. Take Sockton, California for example, a city of only 300K. In it's bankruptcy proceeding, the biggest part of Stockton’s debt is the $900 million it owes to the California Public Employees Retirement System. Wonder who will end up paying for that mess? Right now it looks like the bond holders, but local taxpayers should be on full alert. Anyway, short all you wish, T will be just fine.

Topic.Title: WHAT ABOUT THE 10 BILLION DOLLAR PENSION LIABILITY THAT CANNOT BE FIXED?

Message.Msg: "Wonder who will end up paying for that mess?" Hopefully the retirees who never funded the pension funds in the first place. Same with all of the unfunded pensions. But it will probably be their kids and grandkids.

Topic.Title: WHAT ABOUT THE 10 BILLION DOLLAR PENSION LIABILITY THAT CANNOT BE FIXED?

Message.Msg: KeepShorting,, I'm on your side, the pension liability is a factor, however, it's only a factor if all of the employees take a lump sum pension. But that will never happen because the pension laws do not allow it. I retired recently from T, and one of my reasons was to protect my pension. I wanted my pension in 1 lump sum so my future wasn't in the hands of AT&T. I gave the money to a money manager. It's a risk either way, but I know any retirees who left there pensions with T and they collect a monthly annuity. Once that decision was made they can never change the way they get their pension. And when that retiree die and his spouse dies, all of that pension that is left (which is basically all of the money, because T was only paying the equivalent of the interest it was earning) goes back into the pension fund. Now I'm going to pick a simple number of a pension value for example,, but lets say that every retiree had a pension worth $500,000 and 1% of the 300,000 retirees die this year (all of these are feasible numbers), then $1.5 billion automatically goes back into the retirement fund. Now I know this is a simple look at it and there are more factors, but there are just as many factors that could make this number I made up a low guess as there are that it's a high guess. My point is if all of the mutual funds aren't concerned with it, then maybe you and I need not focus too hard on it. In my case, I took the lump sum to hedge, my 401k that I left 100% invested in T stock (against my money managers advice),, but he's aware of it and has adjusted my portfolio on his part for my stupidity.
Gratitude!!! That is what made America great. Greed!!! That is what is destroying America.

Topic.Title: Hey; what's the matter with T today???

Message.Msg: Wilky, 300 residents is fine for us. No rush hour traffic, no overcrowding at the pristine sandy beaches on holidays, a superb climate with clean air...and like Hesperia, no snow plows. This is truly Paradise Lost. You mention being in the automotive business. Norbert has been looking for a partner in his garage. Maybe you'd like to consider relocating here and take another stab at car repairs again? You would have a guaranteed built-in customer base. The Chamber of Commerce is business friendly and we believe in spending our money locally. We patronize our local businesses by not going to the big city in nearby Frink, Ca. with their new mall. It's good to see your plus $2,5000 for the week. That gets you closer to the 320K you need to make up. Did you ever jump on those May calls you were recommending about 2 weeks ago? Has the run-up changed your thinking? Some of your followers might not be happy with that suggestion if they jumped on it...

Tell you what Wilkie, I don't give a hoot about a 200 DMA or 2,000,000 DMA. I OWN the stock. Have owned it since 1980. Will continue owning it until it changes hands to my son. The company treated me well as an employee and continues to reward me well into retirement. In fact, my cashout in 2002 went right into stock. You and I are at opposite ends of how to investment. Thats fine. You like to play it day by day and hope to profit. I put my money into stock certificates and do profit. As long as we both are above water is all that matters my friend. But I know one thing for certain. I haven't lost any money and don't have to deal with schedule D losses at tax time. I sleep well at home on the Bombay Beach Riviera, cruise the Sea and catch lots of fish from the Niland dock where our boat is anchored.

Topic.Title: Hey; what's the matter with T today???

Message.Msg: Hey Zon. I'm just killing some time waiting for the Spur/OKC game on TNT tonight. The "communities" that Wilkie and I have been exchanging posts about are far from idyllic. I cant speak about Hisperia. Never been there. If Wilky lives there, he is in the Mojave Desert. Not my cup of tea, but I can write about Bombay Beach. Seeings how you're in the great Commonwealth, I doubt you know much about these places. PBS runs a program from time to time about Bombay Beach. If you watched it, you'd probably be grateful you live where you do. I was just messin' with Wilkie. The earthquakes can be a problem in Ca. Fortunately, I actually reside in South Orange County. The soil is sandy here and doesn't cause as much damage as structures on harder surfaces receive. Homes and buildings tend to roll with the punches so to speak during a quake on sand. So no, I'm not really skeered of 'em. That's why I carry earthquake insurance. Expensive, but worth it. Now if we slide into the Pacific... Anyways mate, it was simply having fun with Wilkey. I'm sure he got it. Best regards from the left coast, Dave. P.S. in response to your mention of snow. I'm originally from NJ. I remember an Easter Sunday in about 1967. It snowed. Easter was like the last Sunday in April...very late in the year. A guy coming down a hill hit me head on by sliding into us. No injuries or physical damages to the car or family. Ironically, we were headed to church.

Topic.Title: WHAT ABOUT THE 10 BILLION DOLLAR PENSION LIABILITY THAT CANNOT BE FIXED?

Message.Msg: Zonbac98, I didn't even consider the cost to manage the 401k, when I decided to trust in the T stock. After 30 years with this company, I understand where the upper management loyalty is, and it's not with the peon employees. T values the share holder more than anybody else. So my intent is to capitalize on that knowledge. But I will check into the fees of my 401k and see what they are. Thanks for the heads up.

this action recalls my first-ever trade (1960) after reading a book by Nicholas Darvas, whose philosophy was to look for "...a good advance on strong volume, with favourable fundamental company research...This method also showed Darvas insights into a stock's price behaviour, often revealing the signs of ‘inside buying’ before a company's release of favourable news to the public..."...so the lack of news, high volume and steady price increase would mean (according to Darvas) that insiders are buying on anticipation of something special

Nice take. By "insiders", who do you mean? Most insiders don't have the kind of dough it takes to buy nearly 48 million shares that are on the T board. I doubt they could collectively ante up anywhere near the cost. The A.H. Volume was negligible. Then, I saw it jump from less than 100,000 shares to 45M+. That suggests a hell of a purchase. I know there is a buy back going on, but this action seems way beyond that sort of thing. Daria's makes sense from what you say, but I have NEVER seen this kind of a transaction in all the 32 years I have owned and followed T. It will be interesting to see tomorrows open. 45M shares @37.90=1,705,500,000. That was the value. Thanx for the response. 32 years I have owned and followed T. It will be interesting to see tomorrows open.
Excuse stray duplicated sentence at the end. Typo of some sort.

Topic.Title: WHAT ABOUT THE 10 BILLION DOLLAR PENSION LIABILITY THAT CANNOT BE FIXED?

Message.Msg: Keep shorting friend. You don't need to remember the 45cents shorts owe for the dividend. It will be deducted from your account. T has $40 written all over it, and will still yield 4.5%

How much revenue do my decisions produce? Well, I service on average 120 customers per month. Each of these customers pays ATT on average $100 a $200 or more per month. If I didn't service them, they would change providers. So, with concern to the decisions i make as far as ATT is concerned. I would estimate I add or retain $12,000 to $20,000 per month. With concern to risk, I work aloft and in close proximity to high voltage everyday while on the job. So, I guess you could say I risk my life everyday I work. The company would not exist if they did not have employees keeping everything running and the paying customers happy. I'm sure it disheartens the CEO and those who invest money for a living, but it still takes workers to keep the company making a profit and paying a dividend. You have no way of knowing how much the CEO's decisions make, but I know how much one of his mistakes cost $4,000,000,000.00.
